body:
Sorry for the delay, I just noticed this. If the cond tensor resides in the GPU memory, you can't refer to it from the host. This is however what happens when you call if (cond()) { bla...

The best way to write this is to evaluate the if-then-else directly on GPU as follow:
Eigen::IndexListEigen::type2index<1 rank1;
Eigen::array<int> size = size of the input.
To32Bit(out).device(d) = cond.reshape(rank1).broadcast(size).select(then_flat, else_flat);

Here the reshape allows you to convert the cond tensor to a tensor of rank 1 with 1 element, that can then be broadcasted.

If the cond tensor resides in the GPU memory, you can't refer to it from the host.
